awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  STEM  CATS: Creating Academic Teacher Scholars in STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this University of Kentucky REU project is to prepare STEM teachers by fostering the development of their higher order thinking skills and deep conceptual STEM understanding based on research-confirmed best practices that they, themselves will investigate.  The project will expose 24 pre-service K-12 STEM teachers to timely problems involving STEM teaching and learning through original research conducted with eight successful faculty mentors affiliated with University of Kentucky's STEM Education Department.  The project will also provide experiences that may increase the interest of students from Bluegrass Community and Technical College in becoming K-12 STEM teachers.

During the project pre-service STEM teachers will participate in authentic inquiry into local educational issues with national and international implications such as spatial recognition, informal learning, and mathematics experiences and conceptions. The project will help the students to cultivate an appreciation of the interplay between society and education and research, especially concerning the multiple transformative means of fostering STEM literacy across diverse learner populations.  Students will be exposed to hands-on application of the social-scientific methods that they could eventually practice in their own STEM classrooms.  Students will also be introduced to broader issues impacting these methods such as how ethics affect testing of certain hypotheses and how social biases might influence research with respect to which methodologies are used and how results are reported.  Formative information will be collected each semester from all involved to monitor progress toward goals and guide program improvements.  Summative information will be comprised of longitudinal outcomes data analysis to determine overall impact.  While quantitative data will be used to discover correlations between students' sense of efficacy and likelihood of continuing to research (the Research Self-efficacy Scale and the NSF Biology's Undergraduate Research Student Self-Assessment), semi-structured interviews will be conducted to discover how participants, who vary by a variety of factors, respond individually to the project.

$360,656 - Fisher, M., (PI), Wilhelm, J. (Co-PI). (2015 - 2022). REU Site: STEM CATS: Creating Academic Teacher Scholars in STEM Education

 

Intellectual Merit: The research on this project employs a mixed methods approach as we examined REU fellows' research expectations, familiarity with research literature, and ability to conduct statistical analyses through a survey modified from Kardash (2000) and analyzed qualitative interviews from the fellows' pre-, and post-evaluation interviews. Using a two-tailed t-test, we discovered significant growth in the fellows' confidence levels in studying, conducting, and analyzing research (p < .001) (Wilhelm & Fisher, 2019). Further, our findings showed fellows entered the program with confidence in analyzing literature, but still needed improvement in the areas of designing their own research projects and performing statistical analysis of their research data. Despite their initial confidence, fellows believed this program would greatly increase their abilities to conduct research and write manuscripts for publication. At the end of their nine-month research experiences, fellows stated they felt they had gained skills coding and analyzing data, interviewing skills, using technology, writing, and presenting, but most frequently noted their increase of interpersonal skills and collaborating with peers (Wilhelm & Fisher, 2019).  In a study on the longevity effects the program has on post-baccalaureate careers, we found that while not all fellows remained in education-related fields, they did report that the REU experience greatly impacted them in other ways (Fisher & Wilhelm, 2019).  Most notably, the fellows emphasized how the program improved their writing and presenting skills and prepared them for graduate education. Regarding graduate education, one former REU fellow even stated "There were a lot of people (in my grad program) who came straight out of undergrad, and didn't really know the research process...It was easy for me to transition into doing research full time, because I had that experience working on a project. I first-authored three of my own projects last year in my PhD Program, and that was an easy transition to make" (Fisher & Wilhelm, 2019).

 

Despite struggling with recruiting students from other universities to increase the diversity of our REU fellows, the fellows that have completed the program were quite diverse. While the diversity may not have been as prevalent in terms of racial or gender diversity, the one area that was of particular note was the diversity in the majors of the fellows. While we expected the secondary level majors in mathematics and science education to be interested in a project about STEM education, we were pleased by the number of non-STEM content majors also interested in the program. Of the 24 fellows completing the program in this funding cycle, 10 were secondary STEM majors, 7 were elementary education majors, 2 were special education majors, and 5 were from other majors such as early childhood education, physics, or neuroscience.  In terms of racial backgrounds, we were able to recruit 3 African-American students and 2 Hispanic students.  Also noteworthy, are the 5 community college students and 2 non-traditional students, with one being a veteran retired from the US military.

 

Broader Impacts:  The overall productivity level of the fellows in this funding cycle has been astonishing. To date, these REU fellows involved in this funding cycle have participated in 21 research presentations and have co-authored 10 manuscripts (that are printed or in press) in journals such as School Science and Mathematics, International Journal of Environmental & Science Education, and International Journal of STEM Education, with two other manuscripts currently under review. The PI and co-PI have presented their research from the project at national and international conferences. The accolades of the fellows do not end with scholarship in terms of presentations and publications. Some of these fellows have been awarded summer research grants to continue their work, some went on to participate in a summer REU experience at another research university after leaving their academic year REU program at UK, and many are enrolled in master's degree programs.  One of the fellows summed up her experience with the following, "...it's really eye-opening, and makes me want to continue education research next year, even if it's in a different field. It's something I want to continue and work on."  Another stated, "I think what I've learned is a lot of things that I can take into the classroom...and kind of put [STEM Education] on a pedestal a little because I feel like it's overlooked. I will try to incorporate in my future classrooms and also advocate for the school to incorporate more of it."
